snippet: Global banks are worried that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, federal authorities said.
abstract: Money laundering accusations against British bank Standard Chartered by the New York Department of Financial Services are causing global banks to worry that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators; Standard Chartered is accused of scheming with the Iranian government for nearly a decade and hiding from regulators $250 billion in transactions through its New York branch; accusations center on transactions that the federal government permitted until 2008.
lead_paragraph: Global banks are worried that their New York operations could make them public targets for processing transactions already deemed legal by federal regulators, federal authorities said.

headline.seo: Standard Chartered Case Casts a Chill Over the Industry
headline.main: Standard Chartered Case Casts a Chill Over Banks
headline.print_headline: Accusations Facing Bank Cast a Chill
